metadata.title: Processing and Performance Characteristics of Aluminum-Nano Boron Carbide Metal Matrix Nanocomposites

sections.text:
In this research work, ultrasonic cavitation assisted casting process was used to fabricate the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide metal matrix nanocomposites. The optical microscopy results revealed the refined matrix grains in the microstructure of the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites. Boron carbide nanoparticles were uniformly distributed in the aluminum alloy matrix, which can be confirmed by scanning electron microscopic images. The aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites show increased dislocation density, compared to the monolithic alloys, which was observed from the transmission electron microscopic images. The addition of nano boron carbide in aluminum alloy matrix, significantly improved its hardness and tensile strength, while the good ductility and impact resistance of the aluminum alloy was almost retained. The results of the dry sliding wear pin-on-disc tests showed improved wear resistance properties of aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites compared to the monolithic aluminum alloys. D ow nl oa de d by [ U m eå U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 0 6: 26 0
5 A
pr il
KEYWORDS: Processing, Nanocomposites, Ultrasonic, Cavitation, Properties, Wear, Microstructure
1. INTRODUCTION
In the recent years, metal matrix nanocomposites (MMNCs) have made a significant advancement in different field of engineering. MMNCs do not possess many of the disadvantages found in conventional metal matrix composites (MMCs); such as reduced ductility, poor fracture toughness, and machinability. MMNCs show enormous amount of interest in sports, marine, automobile and defense sectors. The high cost associated with the fabrication of MMNCs hinders their widespread uses [1].
Naturally, nano-sized powders tend to agglomerate more due to the high surface area of nanoparticles. Hence, by using conventional methods it is very challenging to mix the nano-sized particles homogeneously in metal matrices. By considering above concerns, new processing methods are being developed to produce MMNCs with uniform dispersions of nanoparticles. Several methods have been developed to synthesize MMNCs including powder metallurgy, deformation processing, vapor phase processing, and solidification processing. Of the available methods, the least expensive method for the production of MMNCs in bulk is solidification processing. Rapid solidification, infiltration and mixing of nanoparticles followed by stirring are the various avenues available in solidification processing for fabricating the MMNCs [2]. D ow nl oa de d by [ U m eå U ni ve rs ity
L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
Mixing methods that have been applied to synthesize the MMNCs include mechanical stirring, electromechanical stirring and ultrasonic cavitation assisted stirring. In mechanical stirring, a rotating impeller is used to stir a melt that contains reinforcements, creating a vortex in the melt. The major problem associated with the conventional mechanical stirring is, once stirring stops, the particles have a tendency to move to the surface of the melt. Casting process assisted by ultrasonic cavitation is a novel and most promising method to disperse nanoparticles in liquid melt [3].
It has been reported in the literature that the ultrasonic cavitation effects has been used for melt degassing, grain refinement, and deagglomeration of nanoparticles [4–6]. In the context of dispersion of nanoparticles in liquid melts using ultrasonic assisted casting, cyclic high intensity ultrasonic waves are introduced in liquids, which produce ultrasonic non-linear effects namely, transient cavitation and acoustic streaming. Ultrasonic nonlinear effects are responsible for refining the microstructure, degassing of liquids and dispersive effects for homogenizing [7–9].
The implosive effects generated by the high intensity ultrasonic cavitations have the potential to split up the agglomerated nanoparticles and distribute these particles consistently in metal melts. Cavitation bubbles develop localized energy levels many times greater than energy levels achieved by the mechanical mixing or electromechanical mixing. Apart from uniformly dispersing the nanoparticles into liquid melt, the ultrasonic non-linear effects also enhance the wettability between metal melt and nano reinforcements [10–12].

In metal matrix composite category, aluminum (Al) is the most attractive matrix material used particularly in the automobile, aerospace, and transportation industries where weight of structural components is critical. With a Mohs hardness of 9.497, Boron Carbide (B4C) is the one of the lightest and hardest reinforcement materials. Compared to the other ceramic reinforcements, B4C possess very good bonding characteristics with aluminum alloys [13]. Therefore, the addition of high modulus and extremely hard B4C nanoparticles to aluminum matrix develops a high stiffness and high strength aluminum matrix nanocomposites.
Ultrasonic cavitation based nanomanufacturing of A356/nano SiC [1, 7–8] and Mg/nano SiC [9–12] were studied extensively by different authors. The process modeling and deagglomeration of SiC nanoparticles in Al melts were reported in the literature [14]. The fabrication of hybrid composites using ultrasonic cavitation approach was also reported in the literature [15]. Powder metallurgy and mechanical alloying routes were used to fabricate aluminum-boron carbide composites [16–18]. The impact and wear studies of Al/B4C conventional composites were reported in the literature [19].
It is clear from the above discussions that very limited work was carried in the preparation of Al/B4Cp MMNCs using ultrasonic cavitation approach and very little work was done to characterize the Al/B4Cp MMNCs. Hence, in this work, we fabricated the high performance lightweight bulk Al/B4C MMNCs using the ultrasonic cavitation approach and studied their characteristics.

2. MATERIALS AND METHODS

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials For Experiments
sections.text: Aluminum alloy 6061 (AA6061), which contains by weight 0.72% Si, 0.87 % Mg, 0.28% Cu, 0.04% Cr, 0.09% Fe, 0.15% Mn, 0.02% Ti, 0.01% V, 0.01% Zn, 0.02% Pb, and balance Al is used as a matrix material. AA6061 has good formability and corrosion resistance properties along with low density. The reinforcement used in this study is Boron carbide (B4Cp) ceramic nanoparticles (average size 50 nm). There is a possibility of increasing the hardness and other mechanical properties of AA6061 without affecting the overall weight of the component by adding nano B4C. The large difference in thermal expansion coefficient between Al and B4C improve the dislocation density [7]. The improvement in tensile strength is mainly attributed to the high dislocation density. Also the density of B4C is close to Al, hence there will be no segregation during processing. Typical properties of matrix and reinforcement are listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2 Experimental Setup
sections.text:
Figure 1(a) is the indigenously designed aluminum alloy-nano composites fabrication setup, which is provided with an ultrasonic transducer, a variable speed electric motor with mechanical stirrer, a furnace, and an arrangement to supply argon gas. A 165 mm length and 65 mm diameter stainless steel (SS 310 grade) crucible was used for casting the nanocomposites. 2 kW ultrasonic generator converts 230 V line current to high frequency electrical signal at 2 kHz. Piezoelectric transducer converts this high frequency electrical signal into 20, 000 Hz mechanical vibrating energy. These vibrations are coupled to the booster horn which transmits the high frequency vibrations into the melt to D ow nl oa de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve
rs ity
L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
produce intense cavitation. The generator is provided with three different input amplitudes and correspondingly it is possible to obtain three different output amplitudes for melt processing.
The horn shown in Figure 1(b) made of titanium alloy is used for melt processing. The titanium horn has the following dimensions: bottom portion (dipped in liquid) diameter 20 mm, length185 mm and top portion (connected to transducer) diameter 35 mm, length 85 mm in length. The transducer, booster, and horn are tuned devices used to pass the required amount of frequencies inside the melt. Temperature during melting process was monitored by a thermocouple. Compressed air is used for cooling purpose and to partially control the up and down movement of ultrasonic horn during sonication (ultrasonic processing). To avoid the oxidation of aluminum during casting, argon gas is continuously passed on to the melt surface.

sections.heading: 2.3 Experimental Procedure
sections.text:
To understand the ultrasonic non-linear effects on processing the molten materials, experiments were conducted by changing the volume percentage of B4C nanoparticles. 800 grams of aluminum was melted in the furnace at 680 o C and choked for about 10 minutes [20]. Initially, alloy melt was mechanically stirred to obtain the homogenous mixture and then, B4C nanoparticles were slowly added in the molten material from the top. Mechanical stirring is carried out at 700 rpm for pre-mixing the nanoparticles in the Al melt and also to mitigate the sonication time. D ow nl oa de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve
rs ity
L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
After completing the mechanical stirring for primary dispersion, the ultrasonic probe is dipped in the molten material and then ultrasonic wave generator is switched on. During ultrasonic processing, when the intensity (energy) of ultrasonic waves is more than that of the liquid aluminum bonding energy, it breaks the liquid bonds and develops enormous amounts of cavitation bubbles inside the molten material. The implosion of cavitation bubbles during high pressure cycle ensures the dispersion of surrounding nanoparticles in all directions randomly. Hence, the agglomeration tendencies of nanoparticles are significantly reduced after efficient ultrasonic processing. A sonication time period of 45 minutes [7] and intermittent vibrating mode was used for melt processing.
The power rating of the sonication machine used in this study is 2 kW and the horn diameter is 20 mm. The intensity of ultrasound is calculated by dividing the power with horn radiating surface area. Literature results revealed that the ultrasonic intensity of 80- 100 W/cm 2 is quite capable inducing effective cavitation in the metal melts [3]. Therefore the ultrasonic intensity generated in these experiments is quite sufficient to induce effective cavitation and the net effect of this cavitation is to disperse the particles uniformly in alloy melt. Due to the addition of B4C nanoparticles, the viscosity of molten material increases reasonably, which restricts the smooth flow of the molten material into the pre heated steel die. Hence, after sonication process, before pouring the molten material into the die, it was reheated to 850 0 C. In the present work Al/B4Cp MMNCs with different volume percentages (vol. %) of B4C nanoparticles including 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, and 2.5 are fabricated using the ultrasonic cavitation assisted casting method. 3. TESTING OF COMPONENTS

sections.heading: 3.1 Microstructural Observations
sections.text:
Optical microscopy studies are carried out on the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites to study the grain refinement. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies are carried out on the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites to study the particles distribution patterns and fracture. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) is carried out on the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites to study the dislocation density.
In order for any specimen to be observed using optical microscopy, the samples must first be ground, using emery paper of different grain sizes. Then the samples were polished into a mirror like image using alumina slurries and diamond paste in a polishing machine. Finally, the specimens were etched with a solution for a certain length.
Samples for the SEM study are cut and prepared from plain aluminum alloy and each MMNC composition. The SEM samples are made first by polishing with emery sheets of various grades and then by machine polishing using alumina slurries and diamond paste in a polishing machine. SEM and EDS is conducted on HITACHI-S3400N machine and CARL ZESIS SUPRATA make high resolution field emission SEM (HR-FESEM).
TEM specimens are prepared from the plain aluminum alloy and each MMNC composition. TEM was carried out on JEOL make JEM 2100 high resolution TEM machine. Approximately 300 micrometer (µm) thickness specimens are cut from the
D ow

plain alloy and MMNCs, using wire cut Electrical Discharge Machining (EDM). Emery sheets of grades 1200, 1500 and 2000 are used to polish the wire cut EDM samples. Each specimen is polished manually using emery sheets for more than one hour. The thickness of the samples after the manual polishing is found to be around 100 µm. The manually polished samples are mechanically polished to foils of 20 µm thickness, with a surface finish of 50 nm. Dimple grinding and ion milling machines are employed to reduce the thickness of the samples. The disc punch and the ultrasonic disc cutter are used to punch the disks with 3 mm diameter.

sections.heading: 3.2 Hardness Test
sections.text: Brinell hardness tests (MODEL TKB 3000) are conducted as per ASTM E10 standard with 10 mm diameter steel balls and 500 kgf load applied for a specific dwell time of 20 seconds for all the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites. The Brinell hardness number (BHN) is obtained from the average value of five Brinell hardness tests.

sections.heading: 3.3 Tension Test
sections.text:
To study the tensile behavior of the developed nanocomposites, four tensile test
specimens are prepared from each MMNC composition according to the ASTM E8 standard. INSTRON make universal tension testing machine is used to carry out the tension tests. The different in original and final gauge lengths gives the elongation of the sample. UTS and percentage elongation values are calculated for each MMNC composition. The tensile properties are obtained from the average value of four tensile tests.

sections.heading: 3.4 Impact Test
sections.text: To study the impact behavior of the nanocomposites, four Charpy impact test specimens are prepared as per ASTM E23 standard. The Charpy Impact tests are performed on YAMA make impact testing machine on the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites. The impact properties are obtained from the average value of four impact tests.

sections.heading: 3.5 Wear Tests
sections.text:
To analyze the wear behavior of plain alloy and nanocomposites, three Pin-on-Disc wear test specimens were prepared as per ASTM G-99 standards and the pins were tested on DUCOM make Pin-on-Disc wear testing machine. The machine is attached with WINDCOM software, to measure wear, frictional force and the coefficient of friction. The wear properties are obtained from the average value of three Pin-on-Disc wear tests.
4. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
4.1 Microstructural Observations 4.1.1 Optical Microscopy Analysis
Optical microscopic images were taken of the plain Al alloy and AA6061/2 vol.
% B4Cp nanocomposite samples. The results are presented in Figure 2 (a) and (b). Significant reduction in grain size was observed in AA6061/2 vol. % B4Cp nanocomposite. According to classical Hall–Petch theory, the strength of the material increases as the grain size reduces. Ductility and toughness of materials are significantly affected by the grain size. During the solidification of AA6061/2 vol. % B4Cp, the B4C
D ow
nl oa
de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve
rs ity
L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
nanoparticles acted as centre point for non-homogenous nucleation and refinement of matrix grains. The reason for the ductility maintenance in the nanocomposite after adding reinforcement was due to the reduction in grain size of the matrix.
Contrary to most other strengthening mechanisms, grain refinement is attractive
because it does not adversely affect the ductility and toughness of the materials. Dendrite fragmentation and ultrasonically induced nucleation are two mechanisms involved during ultrasonic processing [2]. Ultrasonically induced nucleation observed to be the prevailing mechanism to refine the microstructure. The introduction of high intensity ultrasonic waves in Al melt induces large amount of tiny cavities. The expansion and collapse of these cavities are instantaneous. The temperature of the cavity surface reduces during expansion cycle which results in under cooling and forms solid nuclease. Acoustic streaming transfers these solid nucleases throughout the melt.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Scanning Electron Microscopy
sections.text:
To study the particle distribution pattern in the AA6061/B4Cp MMNCs, SEM images were taken on the specimens. Figure 3 (a) indicate the SEM image of the AA6061/0.5 vol. % B4Cp MMNC. Figure 3 (a) is the evidence for the homogenous distribution of nano-B4C particles in aluminum melt. SEM image of the AA6061/2.5 vol. % B4Cp MMNC is shown in Figure 3 (b). The image clearly shows the microclusters of B4C nanoparticles in the Al melt. During sonication, as the particle volume percentage increases, the mixing of nanoparticles in the matrix was a major problem. Even though the particles were added slowly in matrix, the agglomeration tendency increases as the D ow nl oa de d

particle volume percentage increases. This agglomeration of nanoparticles leads to more microclusters in AA6061/2.5 vol. % B4C nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Transmission Electron Microscopy
sections.text:
TEM specimens were prepared from plain AA6061 and AA6061/2 vol. % B4Cp
nanocomposite samples. Figures 4 show the TEM observations of dislocations in the plain AA6061 at two different locations. The grains of Al, small amount of dislocations and nano-porosity are observed in this image. Dislocations in cast alloys are produced from the growth of the crystal from the melt. As indicated from the high resolution TEM images, more dislocations are observed near the grain boundaries.
Figures 5 represent the TEM images of the AA6061/2.0 vol. % B4Cp
nanocomposites. The images are taken at different locations of the same nanocomposite sample. Greater amount of dislocations are observed in the TEM images. The figures also demonstrate that a much higher density of dislocations exists in the matrix, in a nanocomposite than in the unreinforced alloy. The reason for an increase in dislocations in the nanocomposite can be explained in the following manner.
The presence of reinforcement in metal matrix significantly alters the
microstructure and properties of the matrix material. Even though the load is applied uniformly, the presence of B4C nanoparticles provoke heterogeneous pattern in MMNCs. The CTE mismatch and elastic modulus (EM) mismatch between AA6061 and B4C generates residual stresses in the nanocomposite microstructure. This phenomenon actually

helps to increase the dislocation density in the nanocomposites, when compared to the plain alloys.
During the solidification processing of the composite material, due to a change in
temperature, a mismatch strain εCTE will be induced in nanoparticles, as a result of the CTE mismatch between the Al alloy and B4C nanoparticles; it is given by [21]
CTE m p
C -C T C T (1)
where Cm – Coefficient of Thermal Expansion (CTE) of AA6061,
Cp – CTE of B4C ΔC = Cm-Cp ΔT – Change in temperature.
It is also observed from the images that more amounts of dislocations are
observed near the nanoparticles. It should be attributed to more residual stresses being developed at the matrix-reinforcement interface area. For quantifying the dislocations generated in the as-cast alloy and as-cast nanocomposites, consider an area 200×200 nm 2 as indicated in Figures 4 and 5. For the selected area, the nanocomposites show more dislocations compared to the monolithic alloy.
The deformation mismatch in MMNCs will be restricted by the hard
nanoparticles. Therefore in order to compensate this deformation, large amount of loop like structure will be formed around the surface of the nanoparticles. Because of this, thermal residual stresses are developed in the nanocomposite structure. These thermal residual stresses induce enormous amounts of dislocations in the fabricated composites. The
D ow

by [

pr il

generated dislocations will pile up and interact with each other, which ultimately hinder the movement of dislocations. Hence, the strength of the nanocomposite increases even with the very low vol. % of nanoparticles [22, 23].
When a MMNC specimen is subjected to unvarying compressive loading, the
movement of the matrix is not easily permitted to take place, because of the incorporated hard B4C nanoparticles. It leads to the file up of large amount of dislocation around the surface of the B4C nanoparticles. The increase in dislocations in the MMNC leads to the retainment of matrix yield strength. Volume fraction and the particle size of B4C plays the significant role in deciding the average value of the increase in strength of the matrix. Increase in strength of nanocomposite is attributed to the increase in dislocations and reduction in the size of the matrix grains. Increase of particle volume fraction along with decrease in particle size increases the dislocation density [21-23].

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (Eds)
sections.text:
EDS provision available in the TEM is utilized to validate the incorporation of B4C in the Al matrix. Figure 6 shows the EDS spot spectra on the AA6061/B4Cp nanocomposite. EDS beam actually focused onto a larger spectrum, hence, Al, Si, B and C are observed as high peaks. Oxygen was not observed in this spectrum which indicates that the nanocomposite was protected well during fabrication. This was due to the continuous supply of Argon gas.
4.2 Mechanical Characterizations

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Hardness
sections.text:
The effect of nano-B4C on the hardness behavior of aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites is presented in Figure 7. Increase of particle volume percentage gradually increases the hardness of the nanocomposites. For comparison, plain AA6061 alloy has a hardness value of 40 BHN and the 1.0 vol. % B4C nanoparticles reinforced MMNC has a hardness value of 91 BHN.
The presence of nano-B4C, their good bonding with Al, and homogenous mixing of B4C in the Al matrix by ultra-sonication are the major reasons for the increased hardness of the nanocomposites. The incorporated B4C nanoparticles prevent the movement of dislocations which in turn enhances the hardness. The more the reinforcement added up to an optimum value, more will be the restrictions to the movement of dislocation, therefore the overall hardness of the nanocomposites increased. The downward movement of indenter during hardness test increases the particle concentration near the indentation, which further increases the hardness of the nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Tensile Strength
sections.text:
Figure 8 portray the influence of nano-sized B4C on the tension behavior of Al alloy/B4C MMNCs. It is clear from the figure 8 that by increasing the nano B4C particles content up to 2 vol. %, the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) increases but at 2.5 vol. % it decreases. The ultrafine B4C particles interact with dislocations, which in turn increase the tensile strength. For the specimen with composition 2.5 vol. % of nano-B4Cp, the UTS value actually decreases. This is due to the fact that the mentioned beneficial effect of addition
D ow
nl oa
de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve
rs ity
L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
of B4Cp may weaken the MMNCs by the noticeable porosity content and increased agglomeration of particles.
The mean value of UTS of plain AA6061alloy and AA6061/2.0 vol. % B4Cp MMNC are 125 MPa and 281 MPa respectively. The increase in UTS of MMNC is nearly 125 % when compared to the plain alloy. The large increase in strength combined with the reasonable ductility makes this material as the potential candidature for many structural applications.
The effect of nano boron carbide particle reinforcement on % elongation to fracture for the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide MMNC is presented in Figure 9. It is shown that % elongation, which is a measure of ductility, in the nanocomposites is almost retained for the B4C vol. % up to 2.0. The ductility retention is due the following factors; even though in some areas the B4C particles looked as micro-clusters, these clusters are still separated by nanoparticles. The strengthening and grain reefing effect of uniformly dispersed B4C, balance the negative effect of micro-clusters. Furthermore, the nanocomposites possess superior ductile property over conventional composites. As the particle volume percentage increases beyond 2.0, the reduction of ductility in the composites is significant and it should be attributed to the early void formation and increased porosity content in the above mentioned composites.
4.2.3 Impact Properties

The influence of nano-B4C reinforcement on impact energy of the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites is presented in figure 10. As the volume content of nano-B4C in metal matrix is increased up to 2 %, the impact energy marginally reduced, but, at 2 %, it reduces drastically. This is caused by the failure of B4C nanoparticles by decohesion. The existence of inherent imperfections in the nanocomposite microstructure also influences reduction of impact energy.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Influence Of Nano-B4Cp Vol. % On Wear
sections.text:
The weight loss in the pin is the measure of wear of pin. Figure 12 shows the
variation of the weight loss in the pins for different loading conditions for the MMNCs. For these set of experiments, the following parameters are fixed; track diameter = 50 mm, rotational speed = 500 rpm, sliding velocity = 1.3089 m/s, and sliding distance 500 m.
It is understood from Figure 11 that increasing the content of the nano-B4Cp,
decreases the weight loss in the pins. In general, for all the samples, increase in applied load enhances the weight loss in pins. Furthermore, AA6061 reinforced with 1.5 vol. % of nano-B4Cp shows the lowest weight loss of all the materials tested in this study. This is attributed to the improved hardness by the distribution of very hard B4C nanoparticles that worked as load-bearing elements. The harder the material means more improvement in wear resistance properties. D ow nl oa
de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve

L ib

] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
It is also evident from Figure 11, that the plain aluminum alloy exhibited very
poor wear resistance properties compared to the MMNCs. For example, for the normal load of 39.24 N, the weight loss of the AA6061 is 0.03886 grams, and the weight loss of AA6061/1.5 vol. % nano-B4Cp is 0.01049 grams. This reduction in the weight loss of the MMNC compared to the plain aluminum alloy is more than 136 %, which is a significant improvement for most of the wear resistance applications.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Sliding Distance Vs. Wear
sections.text:
The variation in the weight loss of the plain aluminium alloy and MMNCs with
regard to the sliding distance is presented in Figure 12. The experiments conditions are: sliding velocity 1.3089 m/s and normal load 19.62 N. It can be observed from the graph, increase in sliding distance increases the wear in the pins. For the plain aluminium alloy it increases steeply, compared to the nanocomposites. Increase of rotational speed plays the key role in increasing the wear rate. Increase in rotating speed maximizes the heat production at the interface between Al-pin and disc, which in turn softens the Al-matrix due to excessive aging [24]. The high heat production forces matrix softening, this enhances the wear rate.

sections.heading: 4.3.3 Sliding Velocity Vs. Wear
sections.text:
Figure 13 shows the variation in the weight loss of pins with sliding velocity, for the plain aluminum alloy and MMNCs. The above tests are conducted for the applied load of 19.62 N, with sliding velocities of 1.3089 m/s, 1.884 m/s and 2.189 m/s. The plot shows that the weight loss in both MMNCs and monolithic alloy gets increased with an increase

in sliding velocity. From the figure it is clear, that the weight loss for the nanocomposites reinforced with 1.5 vol. % B4C nanoparticles is lower, compared to the other materials tested in this study.

sections.heading: 4.3.4 Normal Load Vs. Friction Coefficient
sections.text: The influence of normal load on the average value of frictional coefficient for the unreinforced alloys and MMNCs are presented in Figures 14, 15 and 16. The graphs are drawn for three different sliding velocities including 1.3089 m/s, 1.884 m/s, 2.198 m/s and at a stable sliding distance of 2000 m. The increase in normal load and nano-B4Cp content gradually decreases the average frictional coefficient. The friction coefficient is initially high, decreasing to a steady state after about 1500 m of sliding distance. The reason for the higher coefficient of friction at lower normal loads can be explained in the following way: initially contact of asperities is less which results in abrasive action and hence frictional coefficient is high. Increase in normal load leads to good conformity of contact surfaces which reduces the plowing action and also friction coefficient.

sections.heading: 4.3.5 Worn Surface Sem Images
sections.text:
In order to understand the type of wear and wear mechanisms, high resolution
field emission scanning electron microscopic (HRFESEM) images are taken on the plain AA6061alloy and AA6061/B4C MMNCs. Figure 17(a) shows the HRFESEM image of the worn surface of the monolithic Al alloy against the steel disc at a normal load of 19.62 N and at a sliding velocity of 1.3089 m/s. Very few surface shearing and ploughing marks are seen on the pin surfaces. Deep long grooves are seen in the worn out surface of
D ow
nl oa
de d
by [
U m
eå U
ni ve

L ib
ra ry
] at
0 6:
26 0
5 A
pr il
20 15
plain aluminum which is the case of abrasive wear mechanism. In this experiment, aluminum matrix material usually subjected to high wear rate, which depends on disc material and contact pressure.
Figure 17 (b) represents the worn out surface SEM picture of AA6061/1.5 vol. %
B4Cp nanocomposite. It reveals the flat and thin groove like structure at the surface of the pin. The incorporated B4C nanoparticles arrest the material movement during the application of load. The Ploughing observed in hard counterface is lesser than matrix alloy. Strong surface shearing and plowing marks observed on the worn surface of the pin also confirm the above concept. Similar observations are found for the Al pin slid on steel disc. However, the intensity of surface shearing is appreciably increased in the case of the MMNCs, when compared to the plain aluminum alloys.
Figure 18 (a) depicts the HRFESEM image of the worn surface of the monolithic Al alloy against the steel disc at a normal load of 58.86 N and at a sliding velocity of 1.3089 m/s. Plain AA6061 alloy exhibited deep crater as shown in figure 18 (a), which indicates that the plain Al when slides at higher load deform plastically and gradually transmit the matter to steel disc. For plain AA6061 alloy, the wear mechanism is adhesion, which can be confirmed from the worn surface SEM images.
Figure 18 (b) is the worn surface FRSEM micrograph of AA6061/1.5 vol. % B4Cp sample. The experimental conditions are: load 58.86 N and sliding velocity of 1.3089 m/s. It illustrates the coarse type of thin cavity like structure on the worn out face and

these cavities growing along the perimeter of the cavities. Clarke & Sarkar demonstrated this concept earlier [25]. From the worn surface SEM images it can be concluded that the wear type is the mixture of abrasive and adhesive wears.
5. CONCLUSIONS
AA6061/nano-B4Cp metal matrix nanocomposites are successfully developed by
ultrasonic cavitation assisted casting route (Average particle size 50 nm). Results of the optical microscopy indicate that the nanocomposites show refined matrix grains compared to that of unreinforced alloys. The uniform distribution and good dispersion of B4Cp in the Al matrix is obtained; this can be confirmed by the HRFESEM and TEM images. The SEM fracture studies indicate that the type of fracture observed in the composite microstructure is brittle in nature.
The TEM images showed piled up of dislocations in the AA6061/B4Cp MMNCs
compared to the monolithic alloys. In the plain Al alloy, the dislocations are concentrated around the grain boundaries. However, for nanocomposites the dislocations are concentrated around the nanoparticles. The EDS mode in the TEM validates the incorporation of the B4C nanoparticles in the nanocomposites.
Increasing the volume percentage of nano-B4Cp in AA6061 led to a considerable
enhancement in the BHN and UTS of AA6061 while the failure strain and impact strength are almost maintained constant. The AA6061/2.0 vol. % nano-B4Cp MMNC yields a superior tensile strength value. The increase in the UTS in this system is more

than 124 % compared to the cast monolithic alloy. The AA6061/2.5 vol. % nano- B4Cp system possessed maximum BHN value.
The ductility and Impact strength of the nanocomposite are almost retained up to
the addition of 2.0 vol. % of B4Cp; beyond this percentage, the value reduces drastically due to the increased agglomeration of the particles. Compared to plain Al alloy, the ductility and impact strength retention of 95 % and 89 % were achieved for the nanocomposite reinforced with 2.0 vol. % of B4Cp.
The wear studies revealed that the Al alloy -MMNC samples show enhanced wear
resistance properties compared to the monolithic Al-alloys. The wear resistance property increases as the reinforcement volume fraction in Al alloy increases. For both Al-alloys and Al-nanocomposites wear rate increases as the sliding velocity, sliding distance and applied load increases. It is also noticed that increase in wear rate is lower for the nanocomposites compared to that of the plain alloys. The coefficient of friction decreased as the reinforcement volume fraction and normal load increased. The predominant wear mechanism is the combination of adhesion and abrasion which can be concluded from worn surface SEM images.

referenceMentions.context: The high cost associated with the fabrication of MMNCs hinders their widespread uses [1].
Rapid solidification, infiltration and mixing of nanoparticles followed by stirring are the various avenues available in solidification processing for fabricating the MMNCs [2].
Casting process assisted by ultrasonic cavitation is a novel and most promising method to disperse nanoparticles in liquid melt [3].
Compared to the other ceramic reinforcements, B4C possess very good bonding characteristics with aluminum alloys [13].
The process modeling and deagglomeration of SiC nanoparticles in Al melts were reported in the literature [14].
The fabrication of hybrid composites using ultrasonic cavitation approach was also reported in the literature [15].
The impact and wear studies of Al/B4C conventional composites were reported in the literature [19].
The large difference in thermal expansion coefficient between Al and B4C improve the dislocation density [7].
800 grams of aluminum was melted in the furnace at 680 o C and choked for about 10 minutes [20].
A sonication time period of 45 minutes [7] and intermittent vibrating mode was used for melt processing.
Literature results revealed that the ultrasonic intensity of 80100 W/cm 2 is quite capable inducing effective cavitation in the metal melts [3].
Dendrite fragmentation and ultrasonically induced nucleation are two mechanisms involved during ultrasonic processing [2].

During the solidification processing of the composite material, due to a change in temperature, a mismatch strain εCTE will be induced in nanoparticles, as a result of the CTE mismatch between the Al alloy and B4C nanoparticles; it is given by [21]
Increase of particle volume fraction along with decrease in particle size increases the dislocation density [21-23].
Increase of particle volume fraction along with decrease in particle size increases the dislocation density [21-23].
Increase of particle volume fraction along with decrease in particle size increases the dislocation density [21-23].
Increase in rotating speed maximizes the heat production at the interface between Al-pin and disc, which in turn softens the Al-matrix due to excessive aging [24].

metadata.abstractText: In this research work, ultrasonic cavitation assisted casting process was used to fabricate the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide metal matrix nanocomposites. The optical microscopy results revealed the refined matrix grains in the microstructure of the aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites. Boron carbide nanoparticles were uniformly distributed in the aluminum alloy matrix, which can be confirmed by scanning electron microscopic images. The aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites show increased dislocation density, compared to the monolithic alloys, which was observed from the transmission electron microscopic images. The addition of nano boron carbide in aluminum alloy matrix, significantly improved its hardness and tensile strength, while the good ductility and impact resistance of the aluminum alloy was almost retained. The results of the dry sliding wear pin-on-disc tests showed improved wear resistance properties of aluminum alloy-nano boron carbide composites compared to the monolithic aluminum alloys. D ow nl oa de d by [ U m eå U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 0 6: 26 0 5 A pr il 20 15
